144x144

needed to pad to conversation.activity:
(was int32_t)
below 5 fields are 8*4 bytes on x64, 5*4 bytes on x86
3*4 bytes on x86, 4*4 on x64

ld:field.name: unused
ld:field.comment: needed to fix alignment on 64-bit platforms

ld:field.name: continuation
ld:field.comment: When split into multiple lines, set on all but the first

ld:field.name: ID
ld:field.comment: race, item type, plant ID, or shape ID

virtual-methods.vmethod: seems to return like getName1 but with useName true

ld:data-definition.ld:global-type:
"a chosen subject"
"a historical figure" or a specific figure "an abstract concept" or a specific concept

"different readings depending on word breaks" "can be read backwards as well as forwards" "can be read orthogonally across the standard lines" "emerge when reading along certain prescribed paths across the body of the poem"

"originating in ..." "originally devised by ..."
patterns will be tone patterns if set, otherwise accent patterns 'applied by poets to produce individual poems' if set, otherwise 'guides poets during improvised performances'
"certain lines often ... and they sometimes ..."
"is a narrative/... poetic form"
for Histfig subject for Concept subject
"use of ... is characteristic of the form" or "must feature lines which ..."

"line, couplet, tercet" if set, "brief verse paragraphs"/"full verse paragraphs" otherwise
"has X to Y couplets/..."
size_in_lines is set: line, couplet, tercet, quatrain, quintain, etc. size_in_lines is not set: "brief verse" if less than 6, otherwise "full verse"
"the Nth line has XX feet"
"first line must make use of ..."
"The XX line ZZ of ... on YY line" ZZ
YY
XX
for Histfig subjects for Concept subjects
"it has lines with ... syllables" "it has lines with a tone/accent pattern of ..."
"it has ... caesura in each line"
"certain lines have ..." same as additional_features above
"written from the perspective of ..."

-- Civ entities. Non pointers for sites.

enum-item.name: Armor
enum-item.comment: metal.armor, also used for shields, tools, instruments, and toys

enum-item.name: Metal
enum-item.comment: metals with ITEMS_HARD, used for chains

ld:global-object.name: process_dig
ld:global-object.comment: Requests dig designations to be processed next frame.

ld:global-object.name: process_jobs
ld:global-object.comment: Requests building jobs to be processed next frame.

ld:global-object.name: debug_nopause
ld:global-object.comment: Prevents the game from being paused

ld:global-object.name: debug_showambush
ld:global-object.comment: Makes hidden ambushers visible on-screen and in the units list (but not to your citizens)

ld:global-object.name: debug_fastmining
ld:global-object.comment: All dwarves mine as fast as a Legendary Miner

ld:global-object.name: debug_noberserk
ld:global-object.comment: Insanity can only result in Crazed or Melancholy, never Berserk

ld:global-object.name: debug_turbospeed
ld:global-object.comment: All units move and work at maximum speed

ld:global-object.name: save_on_exit
ld:global-object.comment: Ending the game saves its state back to world.dat or world.sav

murder, not aging

ld:data-definition.ld:global-type:
dtor 8532fa0
some value during worldgen, and at the end equals to the number of entities plus that value
unsure but 16-bit values make more sense than 32-bit
11 - necromancers
other: root around in, lick, head-bump, scratch, tusk, retract into shell, roll into a ball often [CDI:CAN_BE_MUTUAL] but not always

enum-attr.name: is_caste_mat
enum-attr.comment: instead of material, uses a creature/caste pair

enum-item.name: BAR
enum-item.comment: Bars, such as metal, fuel, or soap.

enum-item.name: SMALLGEM
enum-item.comment: Cut gemstones usable in jewelers workshop

enum-item.name: CORPSE
enum-item.comment: Corpses. Does not have a material.

enum-item.name: ARMOR
enum-item.comment: Armor and clothing worn on the upper body.

enum-item.name: SHOES
enum-item.comment: Armor and clothing worn on the feet.

enum-item.name: HELM
enum-item.comment: Armor and clothing worn on the head.

enum-item.name: GLOVES
enum-item.comment: Armor and clothing worn on the hands.

enum-item.name: BOX
enum-item.comment: Chests (wood), coffers (stone), boxes (glass), and bags (cloth or leather).

enum-item.name: CORPSEPIECE
enum-item.comment: Body parts. Does not have a material.

enum-item.name: REMAINS
enum-item.comment: Dead vermin bodies. Material is CREATURE_ID:CASTE.

enum-item.name: PLANT_GROWTH
enum-item.comment: Assorted plant growths, including leaves and berries

enum-item.name: THREAD
enum-item.comment: Thread gathered from webs or made at the farmers workshop.

enum-item.name: PANTS
enum-item.comment: Armor and clothing worn on the legs.

enum-item.name: POWDER_MISC
enum-item.comment: Powders such as flour, gypsum plaster, dye, or sand.

enum-item.name: FOOD
enum-item.comment: Prepared meals. Subtypes come from item_food.txt

enum-item.name: LIQUID_MISC
enum-item.comment: Liquids such as water, lye, and extracts.

enum-item.name: GLOB
enum-item.comment: Fat, tallow, pastes/pressed objects, and small bits of molten rock/metal.

enum-item.name: ROCK
enum-item.comment: Small rocks (usually sharpened and/or thrown in adventurer mode)

ld:data-definition.ld:global-type: -- Custom:

ld:field.name: timeout_limit
ld:field.comment: once counter passes limit, mandate ends

ld:field.name: timeout_limit
ld:field.comment: once counter passes limit, mandate ends

ld:global-type.code-helper: (when $.has_name (let* ((nick $.nickname) (lraw $global.world.raws.language) (language $lraw.translations[$.language]) (english $lraw.words) (fname $.first_name) (lwords $language.words)) (flet ((get-words (start end) (loop for i from start to end for word = $.words[i] collect $lwords[word].value)) (get-english (start end) (loop for i from start to end for word = $.words[i] and ps = $.parts_of_speech[i] collect $english[word].forms[ps]))) (list (fmt "Name:~:(~@[ ~A~]~@[ '~A'~]~@[ ~{~A~}~]~@[ ~{~A~}~]~@[ ~{~A~}~]~)" (if (> (length fname) 0) fname) (if (> (length nick) 0) nick) (flatten (get-words 0 1)) (flatten (get-words 2 5)) (flatten (get-words 6 6))) (fmt "aka~:(~@[ ~A~]~@[ ~{~A~}~]~@[ the ~A~]~@[ of ~{~A~}~]~)" (if (> (length fname) 0) fname) (flatten (get-english 0 1)) (when (>= $.words[5] 0) (apply #'format nil "~@[~A ~]~@[~A ~]~@[~A-~]~A" (get-english 2 5))) (flatten (get-english 6 6)))))))

ld:field.name: connections
ld:field.comment: indices into the same component vector

ld:field.name: pump_energy
ld:field.comment: decreases by 1 every frame. powering or manually pumping maintains near 100

enum-item.name: Default
enum-item.comment: dig walls, remove stairs and ramps, gather plants, fell trees

ld:field.name: edge_flow_in
ld:field.comment: if set on an edge tile, water or magma will flow in

ld:field.name: unk13_noncitizen_unit
ld:field.comment: when noncitizen moves in, something happens and it is cleared

ld:field.name: monster_lair
ld:field.comment: A monster lair. Items placed wont be moved.

ld:field.name: no_grow
ld:field.comment: seems to be set on terrain tiles where grass growth is impossible

ld:field.name: update_liquid_twice
ld:field.comment: Protects UpdateLiquid from being cleared the first time.

ld:field.name: repath_on_freeze
ld:field.comment: reindex_pathfinding set and flag cleared if temperature below 10000

ld:field.name: repath_on_melt
ld:field.comment: reindex_pathfinding set and flag cleared if temperature above 10000

ld:field.name: check_aquifer
ld:field.comment: has tiles that may get flooded by an adjacent aquifer

ld:field.name: temp_flow_timer
ld:field.comment: set when water sloshes around, counts down to zero

ld:field.name: unk_2
ld:field.comment: periodically set whenever perm_flow_dir is nonzero

ld:data-definition.ld:global-type:
This is compared to unit.animal.population.depth when a revealed necromancer searches for a map edge tile to run away to:
flood; 256*cost for straight, 362*cost for diagonal
flood; sync to path_distance; same value; inc per run; reset to 0 on wraparound
0 = non-walkable; same nonzero at A and B = walkable from A to B
1 at walkable map edge; then +1 per 10 tiles it seems; 0 in dug tunnels

ld:field.name: sink_level
ld:field.comment: water at or above this level sinks into aquifer tiles

ld:field.name: beach_level
ld:field.comment: water at this level disappears if above more water

ld:field.name: z_shift
ld:field.comment: seems to be 0 originally, but updated when map is shifted

ld:field.name: no_build_item
ld:field.comment: build item is created from scratch upon removing construction, does not exist beforehand

ld:field.name: top_of_wall
ld:field.comment: used on the floors above constructed walls so you cannot remove them

ld:global-type.enum-item: -- the only place where it is not the same as passable_low:

item-attr.name: caption
item-attr.value: tiny tree branch, not strong enough to support creatures

item-attr.name: caption

item-attr.name: caption
item-attr.value: ordinary layer stone. material depends on geology

item-attr.name: caption
item-attr.value: map special stone. used for things like hell, curious structures, or adamantine tubes. material depends on local/global special

item-attr.name: caption

item-attr.name: caption
item-attr.value: vein stone. material depends on mineral veins present

item-attr.name: caption

ld:field.name: parts
ld:field.ld:item:
Contact area of the wound. Is initially the lesser of the weapon or body part contact areas. It grows with cumulative hits. Body parts and non-weapon items have contact=(size/10)^(2/3).
This is strain. For skin/muscle/fat it is usually around 50000, and for bone 100-113. This number heals over time towards 0. A wound that only has strain is called "dented".
A random percentage from 0-100, only for edged damage cases. Otherwise 0. Values above 50 turn straight_scar description into curving scar.
exact location unknown:
This 0-100 percentage is related to cumulative damage. In cases where multiple axe hacks are necessary for severing a limb, it must reach 100 before severing occurs. In cases where a weapon can't completely penetrate a tissue, it is related to the weapon's penetration number. This percentage heals towards 0 over time.
Contact area of the wound. Is initially the lesser of the weapon or body part contact areas. It grows with cumulative hits. Body parts and non-weapon items have contact=(size/10)^(2/3).
This is strain. For skin/muscle/fat it is usually around 50000, and for bone 100-113. This number heals over time towards 0. A wound that only has strain is called "dented".
A random percentage from 0-100, only for edged damage cases. Otherwise 0. Values above 50 turn straight_scar description into curving scar.
exact location unknown:
This 0-100 percentage is related to cumulative damage. In cases where multiple axe hacks are necessary for severing a limb, it must reach 100 before severing occurs. In cases where a weapon can't completely penetrate a tissue, it is related to the weapon's penetration number. This percentage heals towards 0 over time.

ld:data-definition.ld:global-type:
(describe-obj $.name)
-- Number of tiles in the region
-- At most one of 'evil' and 'good' is set at a time by DF.

(describe-obj $.name)
-- Based on worldgen parameter pair.
-- These parameters correspond to -- the similar world gen parameters. -- --

(describe-obj $.name)
-- 0 - 15
Additional river information: The flow element affects the width of the river and seems to follow the formula width = (flow / 40000 * 46) + 1, with a minimum width of 4 and a maximum width of 47. DF uses specific names for rivers with certain flows: - Stream: less than 5000 - Minor River 5000 - 9999 - River 10000 - 19999 - Major River: greather than 20000 Brooks tend to have a flow of 0, but DF has divided the controlling information between this structure, the region map entry (below), and the feature map. Thus, the region map flag 'is_brook' controls whether a water course actually is a (potentially broad) brook or an open water course. Likewise, the 'has_river' flag is needed for DF to properly understand a water course should be present. The exit tile holds the information on which mid level tile the river should exit the region. Presumably the path controls which edge to apply this to. Note that the river up/down/left/right flags of the region map entry should align with the sides rivers enter/exit. The feature map has to have a river entry for the corresponding world tile for a river to be implemented properly. All this is done by DF, but needs to be known if hacking. The world region details (below) data on rivers are generated as the regions are generated. The elevation element affects the level of the river. If the river elevation is lower than the surrounding area DF tends to generate a valley around the river to allow it to reach the correct elevation.

ld:global-type.ld:field: -- Index of the other vein this one is nested in, or -1

ld:field.name: top_layer_idx
ld:field.comment: topmost cave layer the feature reaches

ld:data-definition.ld:global-type:
In order to determine how biomes cross embark tile edges, the rectangle framing an embark tile is split into 4 corners, and 4 straight edge segments, using ranges measured in tiles:
+-/----/+ | / / * | / / +-/-/---+
After this, each corner and edge segment is assigned the biome of one of the adjoining 4 or 2 embark tiles, based on the values in these arrays. It may be necessary to access adjacent details objects to collect the full outline:
c11 x11 | c21 y11 *** | y21 ------------- c12 x12 | c22
There are also certain rules forcing ocean/lake biomes to lose edges to mountains, and both of them to anything else, no matter what the original array value is. The actual biomes for tiles in the frame are semi-randomly interpolated from this edge spec.
(describe-obj $.pos)
-- Rivers crossing embark tile edges

ld:field.name: countdown
ld:field.comment: A counter for stratus clouds that randomly decreases by 1 or 0 each timer weather is checked there. it does various stratus/fog effects based on the humidity/breezes/etc.

ld:data-definition.ld:global-type:
2d byte array with size based on map size
Additional feature_map information: The feature_map is a two dimensional structure dividing the world into 16 * 16 world tile "feature shells" (and remember that there's a single tile wide shell at the end of each dimension, so a pocket world has a shell dimension of 2 * 2). These shells are loaded and unloaded dynamically, which means trying to access a shell that isn't the one in DF's focus (where the fortress/adventurer/pre embark cursor is) is invalid and can lead to DF crashing. The "features.feature_init" 16 * 16 structure contains the features of each of the corresponding world tiles within the shell. However, DF only loads the feature vectors for the world tiles in focus, although they seem to remain loaded until the shell is unloaded. Until loaded the vectors have a size of 0. Manipulation of the features is usually preserved as feature vectors are unloaded/reloaded, so spires can be elongated and rivers added, but some details, such as river fauna, seem to be generated on loading. Added features may not necessarily be reloaded at the vector index they were created at.
